The benefits of urban trees in shading and cooling pedestrian-level environments are significant. Our work investigates the challenge of optimally placing such trees. Physical simulations can estimate the radiative and thermal impact of trees on human thermal comfort but are computationally expensive, making it difficult to optimize tree placements over large areas and consider effects over longer time scales. We employ neural networks to simulate the point-wise mean radiant temperatures, a key factor in outdoor human thermal comfort, across various time scales, from daily variations to extended time scales of heatwave events and even decades. To optimize tree placements, we use the iterated local search framework with tailored adaptations. We demonstrate the efficacy of our approach across a wide range of study areas and time scales. Our approach can empower decision-makers, urban designers, and planners to proactively and effectively assess the potential of urban trees to mitigate heat stress.

Climate change will have significant implications on various aspects of our lives, including the quality of outdoor environments and biodiversity, as well as the safety and well-being of the human population. Densely populated urban regions, characterized by high levels of built and sealed surfaces, are particularly vulnerable to heat stress, which increases the risk of mortality during heatwaves. The mean radiant temperature (Tmrt) is a key factor affecting daytime outdoor human thermal comfort. High Tmrt can negatively impact human health, and Tmrt has a higher correlation with mortality than air temperature. Therefore, climate-sensitive urban planning should aim to lower maximum Tmrt as a suitable climate adaptation strategy to enhance or maintain current levels of outdoor human thermal comfort.

Among the various climate adaptation strategies considered for mitigating adverse urban thermal conditions, urban greening, specifically urban trees, has gained significant attention due to their numerous benefits, including a reduction in Tmrt, transpirative cooling, air quality improvement, and aesthetic appeal. Previous studies have found that the influence of tree positions can be substantial, and other works have optimized tree placements. However, these works were limited by the computational cost of physical models, which made it infeasible to optimize tree placements over large areas or long time scales. There has been increased interest in machine learning for climate science, but previous work has focused on efficiency gains, raising climate awareness, improving analytical capabilities, or using it for urban planning. Our work deviates from these prior works by directly optimizing a meteorological quantity (Tmrt) that correlates well with heat stress experienced by humans.

We present a simple, scalable, and effective optimization approach for positioning trees in urban districts to facilitate climate-sensitive urban planning to adapt to climate change in cities. We use the iterated local search framework to optimize tree placements, and our approach can be applied across a wide range of study areas and time scales. Our work can empower decision-makers, urban designers, and planners to proactively and effectively assess the potential of urban trees to mitigate heat stress.
